Package nl.b3p.brmo.util.http

Class HttpSeekableByteChannel

  • java.lang.Object
    • nl.b3p.brmo.util.http.HttpSeekableByteChannel
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Closeable, AutoCloseable, ByteChannel, Channel, ReadableByteChannel, SeekableByteChannel, WritableByteChannel
    public class HttpSeekableByteChannel
extends Object
implements SeekableByteChannel
    A SeekableByteChannel backed by a HTTP(S) URI that uses the Content-Length response header to provide total size and HTTP Range requests for read-only random access, especially optimized for ZIP archive readers reading only the central directory at the end of the stream supporting a SeekableByteChannel input such as Commons Compress.

    This class assumes most reads to be consecutive like a normal InputStream and sends a HTTP request starting from the current position until the end. When a seek is done using the position(long) method, the HTTP request (if any) is aborted and a new range request is started from the new position until the end, unless it is more optimal to discard some bytes for a small forward seek. This means that the server may receive an error writing its' response with a "Connection reset" error. This strategy is optimal when an application does reads mostly in consecutive chunks.

    Random-access reading code may assume seeks are fast. Even compared to disks using physical platters, HTTP seeks are slow and should be minimized. Aborting a HTTP request should be handled gracefully by a HTTP server but may lead to unwanted "Connection reset" errors. When reading ZIP entries especially, try to avoid reading the local file header and use the central directory only. With Commons Compress this can be achieved by setting the ZipFile constructor parameter ignoreLocalFileHeader.

    This class can be used with any synchronous HTTP client implementation such as Apache HttpComponents, OkHttp, Spring RestTemplate, etc. by providing a HttpClientWrapper to the constructor. This classes uses the Java 11 HttpClient when using Java 11 or higher and URLConnection when using Java 8 if no wrapper is passed to the constructor. These are configured to follow redirects by default.

    If the size() method is called before a Content-Length HTTP response header has been received, the content length is read using GET request with a 0 byte range instead of a HEAD request. This is conceptually similar, but it immediately tests for Range header support and supports redirects if the original URL does not support HEAD requests.

    Because this class may do many requests for certain ranges, a redirect may happen each time. You can optionally update the URI after the first request to the last redirect location using setURI(URI). For Apache HttpComponents this can be retrieved using HttpClientContext.getRedirectLocations().

    This class uses a ResumingInputStream to automatically retry reading the HTTP response when reads fail, until a maximum number of tries.

    The web server must send ETag or Last-Modified headers for use in If-Range request headers. If a weak ETag is sent the Last-Modified header must be present and is used instead of the ETag for the If-Range header.

    This class is not thread-safe.

    Author:
    Matthijs Laan

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor Description
      HttpSeekableByteChannel​(URI uri)
      Creates a read-only seekable byte channel backed by a URI using the default HTTP client, buffer size and max forward seek discard size.
      HttpSeekableByteChannel​(URI uri, HttpClientWrapper httpClientWrapper)
      Creates a read-only seekable byte channel backed by a URI using the specified wrapper around a custom HTTP client implementation using the default buffer size and max forward seek discard size.
      HttpSeekableByteChannel​(URI uri, HttpClientWrapper httpClientWrapper, UnaryOperator<ResumingInputStream> resumingInputStreamWrapper, int seekBufferSize, int maxDiscardSize)
      Creates a read-only seekable byte channel backed by a URI using the specified wrapper around a custom HTTP client implementation, an optional wrapper for the input stream resuming HTTP requests after a read fails, and the specified buffer size and max forward seek discard size.
